Sugar {"&"} Flower
  • Client: Spec Work
  • Timing: 2022
  • Duration: 3 Months
  • Role: UX/UI Designer
The Backstory

To further develop my practical UX/UI Design skills, I completed a self-directed spec project for a mock business, “Sugar {"& "}Flower”. The inspiration for this project came when I was placing an order for a custom cake for my sister{"’"}s birthday and found that the ordering experience offered an opportunity for better design.

Mock brief: Sugar {"&"} Flower, a locally-owned cake shop wanted to increase sales of their custom (made-to-order) cakes. They felt that many customers weren{"’"}t aware of all the options for customization available and additionally the process for placing an order could be simplified. Their existing process for taking a custom cake order was a manual one - with orders being taken in-person or by phone/email. Their website did have a shopping cart and customers could purchase fresh-made cakes available each day from a rotating menu fairly seamlessly. But to purchase a custom cake, customers online were pointed to get in touch with the store directly. A key insight that they shared was that over the past year Instagram became a great source of new customers as the platform did a great job of showcasing the visual appeal of their cake designs.

Problem to Solve {"&"} Core Considerations

The problem of “How to improve the process for ordering a custom cake?” was clear, and to start answering that question, I began with noting the following core considerations:

  • - Improving the process of ordering a custom cake carried different meaning depending on the user (customer vs. shop employee vs shop owner)
  • - They already had a functional website with a shopping cart that could be leveraged towards a solution
  • - There was an opportunity to capitalize on the visual appeal of their cakes to enhance the ordering experience

Research {"&"} Inspiration

  • - Completed competitive analysis of process for taking custom cake orders online, noting key criteria from the experience like complexity, info capture, and use of visuals by competitors
  • - Researched other “made-to-order” online order experiences for inspiration (Domino’s Pizza Builder App, Nike By You Custom Shoes)
  • - Conducted informal iinterviews with actual cake shop/bakery owners

Personas {"&"} Use Cases

Early on in my workflow, I created user personas to apply context to the problem, since “improving the process” had a different meaning depending on the user (customer, shop employee, shop owner, etc.). Key design criteria that surfaced from the use cases I had developed were:

  • - The ordering process needed to be simple to understand and demand low time/energy investment from a customer
  • - An option for 2-way communicatiion should be available during the process, to handle special requests/questions
  • - Guidance/recommendations should be included where unfamiliar options are presented
  • - All customization options that are available should be clearly communicated in the experience
  • - There should be a visual representation of the cake(s) showing customizations as they are applied (similar to Nike and Domino{"’"}s)
  • - Changes to product availability need to be effectively communicated during the ordering process
  • - Ideally the ordering mechanism can connect with CRM and Inventory management systems

Ideation {"&"} Iterative Sketching

  • - Taking inspiration from Domino{"’"}s and Nike, I began by defining a high-level user flow
  • - Organized the content into a series of steps (cards) and completed quick/rough sketches to explore different layouts for the steps
  • - Considered various UI including forms, carousel layouts, and horizontal/vertical steppers in combination with the cards

Concept Development

  • - Determined optimal layout for cards would be a vertical Stepper UI
  • - Sketched various UI options for organizing the contents of each card in the process
  • - Completed additional research on various input types and best practice for usage (fields, checkboxes, drop-down menus, etc.)

Low/Medium Wireframing

  • - Used the low-fi and med-fi wires to improve cohesion, and create consistency across each step
  • - Paid particular attention to designing the interactions for a user moving back and forth between the steps, determining what affordances and feedback needed to be incorporated in to the experience to reduce friction

Final Design

  • - Since the project was spec work for a mock company, I created a mock brand aesthetic (used Ladurée, Fortnum {"&"} Mason, et al. as inspiration) and used this to inform aspects of the visual design (type, colour palette, archway motif, etc.)
  • - Established type styles, colour palette, buttons styles, states, and sourced UI elements to arrive at final design

Outcomes

The first phase of the project provided the opportunity to create a preliminary design solution for the new ordering feature. The preliminary design is ready to be prototyped and tested prior to implementation.

Next Steps

Had the project been for a real-world client (not spec), I would have continued with the following steps:

  • - Build a prototype of the feature
  • - Perform user testing to determine any pain points in the experience that could be improved upon
  • - Organize results from user testing, identifying design opportunities, prioritize {"&"} group tasks and set a timeline for second phase of design

Personal {"&"} Professional Development

This project provided the opportunity to narrow my focus and delve deeper as a UX/UI Designer. Since I was able to direct my efforts towards designing a single feature, I was able to advance several skills essential to UX/UI Design.

Hard Skills (Sketch {"&"} Figma) - I gained practical knowledge and experience with both Sketch {"&"} Figma working on this project and an understanding of the advantages to using each respectively.

UI Best Practices - Particularly when it came to designing the components of the stepper, I relied upon resources that spoke to UI Best Practices to help me determine what the best solution could be. In performing this research, I gained invaluable knowledge on the intricacies of UI and Material Design.

User Personas - This project provided a perfect opportunity to build upon my experience in crafting User Personas. To arrive at a design solution, I had to consider the experience for 2 distinct user groups, delineate the requirement of each group and formulate a hypothesis to solve for a varied list of user needs.
